user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of digest_calc_hash:
```c
_MHD_static_inline void
digest_calc_hash (struct DigestAlgorithm *da, uint8_t *digest)
{
  mhd_assert (! da->uninitialised);
  mhd_assert (da->algo_selected);
  mhd_assert (da->ready_for_hashing);
#ifdef MHD_MD5_SUPPORT
  if (MHD_DIGEST_BASE_ALGO_MD5 == da->algo)
  {
#ifdef MHD_MD5_HAS_FINISH
    MHD_MD5_finish (&da->ctx.md5_ctx, digest);
#ifdef _DEBUG
    da->ready_for_hashing = false;
#endif /* _DEBUG */
#else  /* ! MHD_MD5_HAS_FINISH */
    MHD_MD5_finish_reset (&da->ctx.md5_ctx, digest);
#ifdef _DEBUG
    da->ready_for_hashing = true;
#endif /* _DEBUG */
#endif /* ! MHD_MD5_HAS_FINISH */
  }
  else
#endif /* MHD_MD5_SUPPORT */
#ifdef MHD_SHA256_SUPPORT
  if (MHD_DIGEST_BASE_ALGO_SHA256 == da->algo)
  {
#ifdef MHD_SHA256_HAS_FINISH
    MHD_SHA256_finish (&da->ctx.sha256_ctx, digest);
#ifdef _DEBUG
    da->ready_for_hashing = false;
#endif /* _DEBUG */
#else  /* ! MHD_SHA256_HAS_FINISH */
    MHD_SHA256_finish_reset (&da->ctx.sha256_ctx, digest);
#ifdef _DEBUG
    da->ready_for_hashing = true;
#endif /* _DEBUG */
#endif /* ! MHD_SHA256_HAS_FINISH */
  }
  else
#endif /* MHD_SHA256_SUPPORT */
#ifdef MHD_SHA512_256_SUPPORT
  if (MHD_DIGEST_BASE_ALGO_SHA512_256 == da->algo)
  {
    MHD_SHA512_256_finish (&da->ctx.sha512_256_ctx, digest);
#ifdef _DEBUG
    da->ready_for_hashing = false;
#endif /* _DEBUG */
  }
  else
#endif /* MHD_SHA512_256_SUPPORT */
  mhd_assert (0);   /* Should not happen */
#ifdef _DEBUG
  da->hashing = false;
#endif /* _DEBUG */
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function digest_calc_hash:
#define MHD_SHA512_256_SUPPORT 1
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: Only the controlling expressions of the if-statements (the comparisons of da->algo to the algorithm constants) are relevant to MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 (controlling expressions shall not be invariant). Those if-blocks must be investigated because conditional compilation can remove alternatives and could render the controlling expression effectively invariant in some build configurations. Other parts of the function are not relevant to Rule 14.3: the mhd_assert(...) precondition checks and the function calls (MHD_*_finish, MHD_*_finish_reset) are not controlling expressions; the #ifdef/#endif preprocessing directives themselves are not runtime controlling expressions (though they affect which if-statements are compiled and thus why the above ifs must be checked); there are no loops or do-while constructs in this function that could trigger the rule or its exceptions. Therefore only the listed if-blocks need investigation for potential invariant controlling expressions.
